props.synopsis: South Australia's politicians are heading back to parliament today for the first sitting week of 2025. Here are some of the key issues they will face this year.

title.children: The big political challenges confronting SA's major parties in 2025

image.altText: Kristen De Gilio leans her head into the head of her father John Kennedy

props.synopsis: John Kennedy suffered a sudden cardiac arrest at his Mount Barker home in April 2020. An inquest has heard his wife was told an ambulance was on its way when it had not yet been dispatched.

title.children: Inquest hears father would be alive if ambulance arrived sooner

image.altText: An aerial photo of a large estate on large well-kept lawns, overlooking a marina with docked boats on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Several towns across South Australia will be part of a trial run by the state's electricity distributor to install batteries that it hopes will improve the grid's reliability, increase renewable energy use, and increase the speed at which electric vehicles can be charged.

title.children: Community battery trial a 'win-win-win' for small towns on end of powerline

image.altText: A young man stands under words saying "Punter's Politics".

props.synopsis: A former high school teacher's satirical assault on Australian politics and its taxation failures hits home runs with everyday Australians and he has the federal election in his sights.

title.children: Punter's Politics uses satire to re-engage 'ripped off' Australians

image.altText: aerial shot of Adelaide's water desalination plant

props.synopsis: South Australia's reservoirs are back to the low levels of the Millennium Drought era. But most of us aren't facing water restrictions this time around, largely because the state has something it didn't have back then â€“ a desalination plant.

title.children: Without its desalination plant, SA would probably have water restrictions again

image.altText: Smoke haze

props.synopsis: Temperatures have climbed above 40C in parts of SA, with health authorities confirming several people went to hospital over the weekend with "heat-related illness".

title.children: Weather bureau warns of 'significant' tree branch risk amid SA heat

image.altText: Three abalone shells sitting on a hessian sack.

props.synopsis: Divers off the coast of Port MacDonnell made a grim discovery last February, finding a disease that has sent shockwaves through the abalone industry.

title.children: SA's abalone industry on high alert as 'devastating' disease spreads

image.altText: Hundreds of people dressed as Marilyn Monroe wave.

props.synopsis: More than 700 people dress as Marilyn Monroe have braved scorching temperatures to raise funds for Cancer Council SA during the popular Marilyn Jetty Swim.

title.children: More than 700 Marilyn Monroes take the plunge in jetty swim

image.altText: A politician in a suit with a white shirt walking into a building.

props.synopsis: When South Australian Liberal MP Tim Whetstone faced a challenge to his candidacy, the decision came down to just a few politically engaged party members in his electorate.Â

title.children: Dwindling membership leaves candidates' fate in hands of engaged few

image.altText: A man and woman in a carriage, dressed in formal wear, pulled by a black horse team

props.synopsis: World champion carriage driver Boyd Exell returns home to Australia this year to help students learn the ropes of a sport with royal roots.

title.children: A carriage-driving master brings his skills back home

image.altText: A man stands with shark mitigation equipment, an airhorn and a first aid kit.

props.synopsis: Streaky Bay local Danny Lee, who is frustrated the community has been left to mitigate the risk of shark attacks on their coastline, is asking the government to increase funding to protect ocean users.Â

title.children: Community demands more shark mitigation funding after fatal SA attacks

image.altText: A man wearing long sleeves, a broad brimmed hat and sunglasses stands on a pitch, light blue sky, trees in the background.

props.synopsis:
Over a year on from several Australian organisations officially recognising participation in outdoor sport as a factor in the development of skin cancer, efforts to protect players in community sports remain "patchy".
Â

title.children: Call for community sporting clubs to better protect members from skin cancer

image.altText: A blazing orange sun sits above golden clouds.

props.synopsis: Authorities continue to battle several bushfires in the state's west, with temperatures expected to again reach extreme levels before the cool change.

title.children: Cool change coming for parts of Victoria but heat and fires elsewhere

image.altText: A specialist checks the skin of a patient.

props.synopsis: When specialist referrals expire, some patients are being charged twice for more costly initial consultations, despite their care being ongoing. Health experts say it's a potentially illegal practice that's costing patients. Â

title.children: How repeat referrals are costing Medicare and patients

image.altText: A burnt-out building stands among burnt out trees on a country property.

props.synopsis: Grassfires sparked by lightning destroyed at least two homes in Victoria's north west overnight, with fears of more property losses to come as heatwave conditions continue across the state until Tuesday.

title.children: Lightning sparks new fires, houses destroyed as Victoria's heatwave continues

image.altText: A woman holds a $50 note and two $20 notes for a story about superannuation.

props.synopsis: Topping up your super can boost your retirement savings, but with so many competing financial priorities, how do you know when it's the right time to contribute?Â

title.children: What to consider before making voluntary super contributions

image.altText: A police car on a beach. People standing around multile pop up tents.

props.synopsis: Paramedics from the Queensland Ambulance Service were called to Woorim Beach shortly before 5pm today.Â

title.children: Seventeen-year-old girl killed in shark attack at Bribie Island

image.altText: A large lightning bolt hits the ground at night with city lights and a bridge illuminated.

props.synopsis: Dry lightning strikes have been blamed for causing a number of bushfires across Victoria. But what's the difference between dry and wet lightning?Â

title.children: What is dry lightning and how does it start bushfires?

image.altText: A large rainbow flag is waved in the air.

props.synopsis: The government will need to rely on the crossbench to pass proposed legislation, with the opposition concerned those claiming a political stance will be able to circumvent the laws.

title.children: Plans to expand Victoria's hate speech laws face opposition road block

image.altText: A towering red rock over a desert landscape.

props.synopsis: Police say the 77-year-old Queensland woman was visiting Mount Augustus in WA's remote Gascoyne, where temperatures reached the high 40s over the weekend.

title.children: Tourist dies after leaving bogged car in heatwave conditions in WA

image.altText: A woman wearing a red suit walks outside of court.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Antoinette Lattouf have revealed private messages between senior ABC executives in Federal Court, arguing the journalist and presenter was fired due to her opinions about the conduct of the Israeli government in Gaza.

title.children: 'We owe her nothing': Buttrose's emails on Lattouf's departure revealed in court

image.altText: Close up of Alex Dyson smiling

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton is fighting to keep seats that were once considered unlosable as independents â€” better funded and better organised than before â€” join the race.

title.children: How a contest between a DJ and a former minister, could put Dutton's bid for power at stake

image.altText: Three people smiling for photo on a removalist truck

props.synopsis: When this Hobart hotel was doing its refurbishment, it knew it didn't want all the old furniture to end up in landfill. Now, it's helping create a cosy home for women at risk of homelessness.

title.children: 'Rather than going to landfill': Hotel's big donation goes to refuge

image.altText: Hospital workers in scrubs and pink shirts picket with signs protesting lack of air conditioning.

props.synopsis: With room temperatures reportedly reaching around 30 degrees inside the Launceston General Hospital, staff and patients have been given frozen treats to help them cope because of inadequate air-conditioning.

title.children: Ice treats given to patients, staff as hospital grapples with aircon fix

image.altText: A door smashed through, with shops in the background.

props.synopsis: Police say a person in a red Ford Falcon ute drove through the front glass doors of Gippsland Centre in Sale before exiting on the other side and fleeing the scene.

title.children: People duck for cover as man drives ute through Sale shopping centre

image.altText: A woman standing outside her home

props.synopsis: Kaye Powell is preparing to cut her 99-year-old Reservoir home in half, put it on the back of a truck and transport it almost 100 kilometres away to Malmsbury.

title.children: The 100km journey to give a century-old Victorian home a new life

image.altText: A chicken parmigiana sits atop chips and a side salad on a white plate, which is on a wooden bench

props.synopsis: Labor says the Coalition's election policy to offer tax-free lunches would cost the federal budget $1.6 billion a year, enlisting the Treasury in a political attack on the small business support measure Treasurer Jim Chalmers says would "smash the budget".

title.children: Angus Taylor says Treasury costing of his lunch policy 'egregious politicisation'

image.altText: A woman holds a $50 note and two $20 notes for a story about superannuation.

props.synopsis: Topping up your super can boost your retirement savings, but with so many competing financial priorities, how do you know when it's the right time to contribute?Â

title.children: What to consider before making voluntary super contributions

image.altText: A large pile of books and other debris outside a library building reaches almost to the second floor windows.

props.synopsis: When floods decimated the Lismore City Library in 2022, photos of the damage sparked a national outpouring of donations. At last, the space has reopened to the public.

title.children: 'Exhilarating' day as library reopens after floods destroyed 29,000 books

image.altText: A crocodile at the waters edge jumping over a wave.

props.synopsis: Campers at a popular Queensland campsite are being warned to stay off the beach following a "credible" crocodile sighting.

title.children: Beachgoers warned of 'vagrant' crocodile near Queensland's Rainbow Beach

image.altText: A boy goes to give an excited Albanese a high five in a classroom

props.synopsis: The federal government is daring its opponents to vote down a bill guaranteeing three days a week of subsidised child care for all families, bringing forward a promise Labor was expected to take to the federal election.

title.children: Three-day childcare guarantee could pass parliament this fortnight

image.altText: A man speaking to a crowd with a backdrop of tropical plantlife.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people have attended a state funeral for former judge and NT administrator Austin Asche, remembering him as an "excellent judge" who devoted his time to fostering the next generation of NT leaders.

title.children: Former judge and NT administrator Austin Asche farewelled at state funeral

image.altText: A small black whale with a white oval-shaped marking on its side pokes out of the water.

props.synopsis: A newborn killer whale calf spotted off the southern coast of WA could be one of the youngest ever seen in Australian waters.Â

title.children: Rare sighting of newborn orca off the WA coast

image.altText: A sign on top of a shelf of American whiskey says "Buy Canadian instead" with a red maple leaf

props.synopsis: US alcohol is just one of the products targeted for boycott and possible tariffs, Canadian authorities say.

title.children: Canada fights back against US tariffs as American products boycotted

image.altText: two carton eggs

props.synopsis: Police will allege in court that inquiries revealed the attack was random after a group of young women in Sydney's east reported having eggs thrown at them over the weekend.

title.children: Egging of women in Bondi not antisemitic, police say
